com.quest.glue.api.services
Interface LogService

All Superinterfaces:
Service
public interface LogService
extends Service

A service that will provide logging to agents, agent factories, and related classes.

Good logging is essential to post mortem debugging and problem solving. Since we will not have access to customer's machines a good set of logs is crucial.

Glue will provide a logging service for all agents (both in- and out-of-process) that will allow them to record anything they want to. Output to the console (via stdout or stderr) is strongly discouraged and will not be allowed for in process agents. All output should be done through the logging service.

The canonical usage is: 

   private final Logger LOG;
   public AClass(...) {
       LOG = ServiceFactory.getService(LogService.class).getLogger(AClass.class);
   }

Please do not use a static log variable in your class if there is any possibility that the class could be used in more than one instance of an agent. All the loggers will be customized to a specific agent when returned by the Log service.

The logging service is fully internationalized, but it is the responsibility of the agent developer to provide their own localization files, as appropriate. Agent will not be able to control where log messages get written or any other meta data about logging such as maximum log size, log file names, log formatting. These will be controlled by Glue and will be the same for all agents.

The following log levels are available:

LevelDescription
FATAL
ERROR
WARN
INFO
VERBOSE
CONFIG (not recommended, use VERBOSE instead)
DEBUG
DEBUG2

All log messages (except DEBUG, DEBUG2, ignored exceptions, and unexpected errors) must be internationalized. This is done by creating a file called LogResources.properties in the same package as the class for which it holds log messages. The file must conform to the Java property file format and will contain both the log text and log level for all messages use by all classes in the package. Logging calls are then made using the ID of the log message. The logging system is responsible for looking up the actual message text and doing all parameter replacements.

For example, in com/quest/blah/blah/LogResources.properties: 

      AClass.aLogKey = This is a log messages with 3 parameters: {0} {1} {2}
      AClass.aLogKey.level = WARN

and the corresponding usage in com.quest.blah.blah.AClass would be: 

      Logger.log("aLogKey", new Object[]{param0, param1, param2});
      Logger.log("aLogKey", new Object[]{param0, param1, param2}, (Throwable)someException);

DEBUG and DEBUG2 log messages do not need to be internationalized and their text can be embedded in the code instead of in the LogResources.properties file.

Log messages at INFO level or higher are written to the console in addition to any log files they might be redirected to. VERBOSE messages are only written to log files. DEBUG and DEBUG2 messages are written to the console only when the system property quest.debug is set to 1 or higher.

Agents should not need to worry about checking the current debug level. Simply choose the correct log level for the message and the logging system will ensure only those messages appropriate for the current log level are propagated.

All exceptions must be logged in some fashion or another, even if they are explicitly ignored. The LogService.Logger.ignoreException(String,Throwable) method can be used to ignore an exception.

Since:
5.2.0
See Also:
LogService.Logger

          Handles all log messages for a single class.

Method Detail

getDebugLevel

int getDebugLevel()
Returns 0 if the log level is set to INFO (the default) or higher. Otherwise if returns the debug level set by the global system property "quest.debug".

A value of 1, corresponding to "-Dquest.debug=1", means that Logger.debug() messages will be printed. A value of 2 means that Logger.debug2() messages will be printed. Higher values are treated the same as 2.

You can use this value to add guards around expensive debug logging statements so that they are only constructed as passed when they are going to be used.

Returns:
0 or a positive integer, indicating the current debug level.

getLogger

LogService.Logger getLogger(java.lang.Class clazz)
Returns an class that implements the Logger interface. This can be used for all log messages in the specified class.

Parameters:
clazz - The class that the returned logger is to be customized for. The logger should only be used in an instance of the provided class.
Returns:
A Logger instance tagged for the given class
